case_name: Income-tax Officer, Nizamabad Circle v. Rajareddy Mallaram

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 290 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 290 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 19, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in case referred No. 7 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 19, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in case referred No. 7 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SHAH, J. on November 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: November 20, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Baba Gowd, P.V. Rajareddy and Rajareddy Mallaram formed an association of persons called Nizamabad Group Liquor Shops (the Group).

anchor.surface_text: Baba Gowd, P.V. Rajareddy and Rajareddy Mallaram formed an association of persons called Nizamabad Group Liquor Shops-called for the sake of brevity the Group.

facts.text: The Group carried on business in liquor contracts obtained from the former State of Hyderabad for Fasli year 1358 i.e. October 1, 1948 to September 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: For the Fasli year 1358 i.e. October 1, 1948 to September 30, 1949 the Group carried on business in liquor companytracts obtained from the former State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: End of Fasli year 1358 the contracts came to an end, business discontinued, and the Group was dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: With the end of Fasli year 1358 the companytracts came to an end. The business was then discontinued, and the Group was dissolved.

facts.text: The Group did not make a return of its income pursuant to the general notice under s. 22(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Group did number make a return of its income pursuant to the general numberice under s. 22 1 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Nizamabad Circle, issued a notice under s. 34 to Baba Gowd to file a return of the income of the Group.

anchor.surface_text: The Incometax Officer, Nizamabad Circle, issued a numberice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act calling upon Baba Gowdone of the members of the Group-to file a return of the income of the Group,

facts.text: Baba Gowd failed to file the return on the due date.

anchor.surface_text: but Baba Gowd failed to file the return on the due date.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed the taxable income of the Group under s. 23(4) at Rs. 51,000 and determined tax payable at Rs. 8,826-14-0.

anchor.surface_text: The Incometax Officer then assessed the taxable income of the Group under s. 23 4  at Rs. 51,000, and determined Rs. 8,826-14-0 as the tax payable.

facts.text: Attempts by Income-tax Department to recover tax from Baba Gowd proved unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Attempts made by the Income- tax Department to recover the tax from Baba Gowd having proved unsuccessful,

facts.text: On March 13, 1954, Income-tax Officer issued notice of demand to Rajareddy Mallaram.

anchor.surface_text: on March 13, 1954, the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice of demand addressed to Rajareddy Mallaramanother member of the Group.

facts.text: Rajareddy Mallaram applied under s. 27 for cancellation of the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The latter then applied under s. 27 of the Indian Income-tax Act for can- cellation of the assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the application under s. 27.

anchor.surface_text: The application was rejected by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner set aside the order and directed Income-tax Officer to cancel assessment under s. 23(4) and make fresh assessment after opportunity to file return and produce books.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the order was set aside and the Income-tax Officer was directed to cancel the order of assessment under s. 23 4  and to make a fresh assessment after giving an opportunity to Rajareddy Mallaram to file a return and to produce the books of account of the dissolved Group.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad Branch modified the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad Branch modified the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal held valid assessment under s. 23(4) already made, no occasion for fresh notice or assessment, but directed Appellate Assistant Commissioner to consider sufficient cause for return.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that a valid order of assessment under s. 23 4  having already been made in the case there companyld be numberoccasion to issue a fresh numberice to Rajareddy Mallaram or to make a fresh assessment, but somewhat inconsistently with that opinion, the Tribunal directed that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner do companysider whether Rajareddy Mallaram had been prevented by sufficient cause from making the return.

facts.text: At instance of Rajareddy Mallaram, Tribunal referred two questions to Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of Rajareddy Mallaram the following two questions were referred to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by the Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court answered first question in the affirmative (order bad in law) and held second question did not fall to be determined.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and held that the second question did number fallto be determined.

facts.text: High Court found assessment under s. 23(4) on 30-9-1953 bad in law because assessed association not members jointly and severally and no notices under ss. 34 and 22(4) served on petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the order of assessment made by the Income-tax officer under section 23 on 30-9- 1953 is bad in law,  a  absolutely, because he Made the assess- ment of the association and number of those who were members of the association at the time of the dissolution jointly and severally and  b  particularly as against any member on whom numberices under sections 34 and 22 4  were number served because of such failure to serve numberices on him.

facts.text: High Court held assessment not binding on petitioner as no notice under s. 22 issued to him and not assessed severally or jointly.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment is number binding on the petitioner, as numbernotice under section 22 was issued to him and as he was number assessed severally or jointly with others referred to above.

facts.text: High Court held applicant not liable for tax as assessment not in conformity with s. 44.

anchor.surface_text: The applicant is number liable for the amount of tax payable as determined in the order of assessment dated 30-9-1953, as that assessment was number made in companyformity with section 44 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Group admittedly discontinued its business and was dissolved at the end of Fasli year 1358.

anchor.surface_text: The Group admittedly discontinued its business at the end, of Fasli year 1358 and it was also dissolved.

facts.text: Every member of the Group at time of dissolution was jointly and severally liable under s. 44 for assessment and tax.

anchor.surface_text: Every person who was at the time of such discontinuance or dissolution a member of the Group was by the express terms of s. 44 liable to be assessed jointly and severally in respect of, the,, income, profits and gains of the Group and was also liable for the amount of tax payable.

facts.text: No contention raised before Tribunal that notice under s. 34 was not properly served on Baba Gowd as principal officer.

anchor.surface_text: But numbersuch companytention was raised before the Tribunal. It does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal and the question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court does number. justify companysideration of that plea.

facts.text: Supreme Court held order of assessment under s. 23(4) valid.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the answer to the first question will be in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court held applicant liable for tax payable under the order of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The second question will be answered as follows The applicant was liablefor the amount of tax payable under the order of assessment.

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed.

concepts.unlisted_description: Joint and several liability of members on discontinuance or dissolution of association

anchor.surface_text: The material part of s. 44 of the Indian. Income-tax Act  insofar as it dealt with the liability of discontinued associations  before it was amended by s. 11 of Finance Act XI of 1958 with effect from April 1, 1958, stood as follows Where any business, profession or vocation carried on by a association of persons has been discontinued, or where an association of persons is dissolved, every person who was at the time of such discontinuance of dissolution a member of such association shall, in respect of the income, profits and gains of the . . association, be jointly and severally liable to assessment under Chapter IV and ,for the amount of tax payable and all the provisions of Chapter IV shall, so far as may be, apply to any such assessment.

concepts.interpretation: Court interprets s.44 as declaring joint and several liability for assessment under Chapter IV post-dissolution; creates fiction of continuity of association for assessment purposes as a unit; notice to principal officer sufficient; members liable even if not personally served.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: d ,for the amount of tax payable and all the provisions of Chapter IV shall, so far as may be, apply to any such assessment. The section declares the

issues.text: On the facts and in the circumstances of the case, was the order of assessment made by the Income-tax Officer under section 23(4) on 30-9-1953 bad in law?

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of Rajareddy Mallaram the following two questions were referred to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by the Tribunal. On the facts and in the circumstances of the case, was the order of assessment made by the Income-tax Officer under section 23 4  on 30-9-1953 bad in law?

issues.text: If the answer to the above question is in the negative, was the applicant liable for the amount of tax payable as determined in that order of assessment by reason of the terms of section 44 of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to the above question is in the negative, was number the applicant liable for the amount of tax payable as determined in that order of assessment by reason of the terms of section 44 of the Income-tax Act? The High Court answered the first question

issues.text: whether the order of assessment made by the Income-tax Officer, subsequent to the dissolution of the Group, assessing its income, after serving a notice upon one and not all the members of the Group, could be enforced against members of the Group who were not served.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question which fell to be determined before the taxing authorities was whether the order of assessment made by the Income-tax Officer, subsequent to the dissolution of the Group, assessing its income, after serving a numberice upon one and number all the members of the Group, companyld be enforced against members of the Group who were number served.

arguments.claim: Section 44 declares joint and several liability of members to assessment under Chapter IV and applies Chapter IV provisions to such assessment

anchor.surface_text: The material part of s. 44 of the Indian. Income-tax Act  insofar as it dealt with the liability of discontinued associations  before it was amended by s. 11 of Finance Act XI of 1958 with effect from April 1, 1958, stood as follows Where any business, profession or vocation

arguments.claim: By fiction under s.44, association continues for purpose of assessment under Chapter IV despite dissolution

anchor.surface_text: The section declares the liability for assessment under Ch. IV of the Act in case of discontinuance, of the business of or dissolution of an association. ... In effect, the Legislature has enacted by s44 that the assessment proceedings may be companymenced and companytinued against a firm of which business is discontinued as if discontinuance has number taken place.

arguments.claim: Association of persons assessed as unit under Chapter IV, not members collectively or partially; no machinery for assessing association income in hands of members collectively

IV of the Income-tax Act an association

arguments.claim: Assessment under s.23(4) valid; answer to first question in negative

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the answer to the first question will be in the negative.

arguments.claim: Applicant liable for tax payable under the order of assessment; answer to second question yes

holdings.text: The answer to the first question is in the negative: the order of assessment made by the Income-tax Officer under section 23(4) on 30-9-1953 was not bad in law.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the answer to the first question will be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 44 creates a legal fiction continuing the dissolved association as a unit for assessment under Chapter IV; assessment of the association binds all members jointly and severally; notice served on principal officer Baba Gowd sufficient; follows Abraham precedent rejecting need for individual service on all members.

holdings.text: The applicant was liable for the amount of tax payable under the order of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The second question will be answered as follows The applicant was liablefor the amount of tax payable under the order of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: By express terms of s.44, every member at dissolution is jointly and severally liable for tax on valid assessment of the association's income.

holdings.text: A notice to the appropriate person under s. 63(2) is sufficient to enable the authority to assess to tax the association; personal service on respondent not required.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice to the appropriate person under s. 63 2  would, therefore, be sufficient to enable the authority to assess to tax the association. The plea that the respondent number having been served personally with the, numberice of assessment is number liable to pay the tax,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44 applies Chapter IV assessment machinery to dissolved association as if continuing; service on principal officer represents the association unit; individual members liable without personal notice.

holdings.text: The case must be decided on the footing that notice of assessment was properly served on Baba Gowd who was the principal officer and that the assessment was properly made by the Income-tax Officer under s. 23(4).

anchor.surface_text: the assessment, was properly , made by the Income-tax Officer tinder s. 23 4 . We hold that the answer to the first question will be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No contention of improper service on principal officer raised before Tribunal or in reference; cannot be raised now.

holdings.text: Every person who was at the time of discontinuance or dissolution a member of the Group was jointly and severally liable to assessment under Chapter IV and for the tax payable thereon.

anchor.surface_text: Every person who was at the time of such discontinuance or dissolution a member of the Group was by the express terms of s. 44 liable to be assessed jointly and severally in respect of, the,, income, profits and gains of the Group and was also liable for the amount of tax payable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of s.44 to facts of dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding assessment invalid and applicant not liable; reverses High Court judgment.
